deliberation: Checked for metaphors, idioms, and personification. Narrative is mostly literal, but the prophetic formula 'the word that came to Jeremiah from YHWH' personifies the divine message as a thing that can 'come' and functions metonymically for revelation.

instances.english_text: The word that came to Jeremiah from GOD
vehicle: a 'word' that physically comes to someone
ground: a message arriving and initiating contact with a person
posture: narrator’s description of how Jeremiah receives revelation
instances.explanation: The divine revelation is described as a 'word' that 'came' to Jeremiah, personifying the message and using a movement metaphor for God’s act of revealing.

deliberation: Looked for metaphor, idiom, and metonymy. The speech is straightforward, but 'this place' stands for the city and its inhabitants, a common metonymy.

instances.hebrew_text: יְהוָה אֱלֹהֶיךָ דִּבֶּר אֶת־הָרָעָה הַזֹּאת אֶל־הַמָּקוֹם הַזֶּה
instances.english_text: The ETERNAL your God threatened this place with this disaster
target: the people and city of Jerusalem/Judah who will suffer judgment
ground: close association between a place and the people who live there
instances.explanation: ‘This place’ refers not only to the soil but to the city and its inhabitants, using the location metonymically for the community under judgment.

deliberation: Searched for metaphor and idiom. The causal explanation is literal, but the expression ‘you did not listen to His voice’ is a standard idiom for disobedience, conceptualizing obedience as listening to a voice.

instances.english_text: and did not pay heed [lit. ‘did not listen to His voice’]
ground: obedience pictured as attentive listening to speech
instances.explanation: The idiom ‘listen to His voice’ metaphorically frames obedience to God as hearing and heeding a spoken voice.

deliberation: Examined the release speech for idioms and metaphors. Found three: (1) ‘I will set my eye on you’ for protective care, (2) ‘the whole land is before you’ picturing freedom of choice as an open expanse, and (3) ‘what is good/right in your eyes’ as a visual idiom for personal evaluation.

instances.english_text: and I will look after you [lit. ‘I will set my eye on you’]
target: Jeremiah’s protection and welfare under Babylonian authority
ground: constant watchfulness implies protection and concern
instances.explanation: The phrase uses a body-part metaphor: fixing one’s ‘eye’ on someone stands for sustained protective attention and care.

instances.english_text: See, the whole land is before you
target: Jeremiah’s unrestricted options about where to live
vehicle: an open land lying in front of a person
ground: having an open expanse before you evokes freedom and lack of barriers
instances.explanation: Jeremiah’s range of choices is pictured as an open land spread out before him, an idiomatic metaphor for full freedom of choice.

instances.hebrew_text: אֶל־טוֹב וְאֶל־הַיָּשָׁר בְּעֵינֶיךָ לָלֶכֶת שָׁמָּה לֵךְ
instances.english_text: go wherever seems good and right to you [lit. ‘what is good and right in your eyes’]
vehicle: what appears good/right in someone’s eyes
ground: liking something as ‘seeing it as good’
posture: Nebuzaradan deferring to Jeremiah’s own judgment
instances.explanation: The idiom uses visual language (‘in your eyes’) to describe Jeremiah’s inner judgment and moral assessment.

deliberation: Most of the verse is logistical and literal. The one figurative element is again the idiom ‘what is right in your eyes to go, go,’ using visual language for internal evaluation.

instances.english_text: or go wherever you want to go [lit. ‘wherever is right in your eyes to go, go’]
target: Jeremiah’s own sense of what course of action is appropriate
vehicle: visual perception of something as straight/right
ground: rightness is conceptualized as straightness perceived visually
alignment with one’s sense of propriety
posture: granting freedom framed in visual-ethical terms
instances.explanation: The idiom uses what is ‘right in your eyes’ to describe Jeremiah’s internal moral and practical evaluation, mixing visual and ethical metaphors.

deliberation: Narrates Jeremiah’s movement to Gedaliah and his residence among the remaining people. Expressions like ‘among the people who were left in the land’ are literal descriptions of location and status, not figurative.

Describes who heard what, and administrative appointments. Phrases like ‘officers in the field’ and ‘from the poorest of the land’ are socio-geographical labels here, not functioning as metaphors or idioms.
This verse is a list of names and places, narrating who came to Gedaliah. I did not find metaphors, idioms, or other figurative devices; all elements function literally.

Investigated ‘serve the Chaldeans’ and ‘it will be good for you.’ In this political context ‘serve’ means literal political subjection, and ‘it will go well with you’ is a straightforward outcome statement, not heightened or figurative.
Most of the verse is practical instruction. The idiom ‘to stand before the Chaldeans’ is figurative for serving or representing them in an official capacity.

instances.hebrew_text: הִנְנִי יֹשֵׁב בַּמִּצְפָּה לַעֲמֹד לִפְנֵי הַכַּשְׂדִּים
instances.english_text: I am going to stay in Mizpah to attend upon the Chaldeans [lit. ‘to stand before the Chaldeans’]
target: Gedaliah’s role of service and representation before Babylonian authorities
ground: court officials literally stand before their superiors; standing signals readiness to serve
status and subordination expressed by bodily posture
posture: Gedaliah’s self-description of his political function
instances.explanation: ‘Standing before’ the Chaldeans is an idiom picturing official service as the physical posture of standing in a superior’s presence.

deliberation: The verse reports that the king of Babylon left ‘a remnant’ of Judah and appointed Gedaliah. Here ‘remnant’ is used in its straightforward sense ‘survivors’ without clear figurative extension; the language reads as literal.

Looked for imagery in the verbs of movement. The phrase ‘from all the places to which they had been driven’ uses a verb of pushing/driving for exile and is rendered ‘scattered’; this conceptualizes exiles as objects driven or scattered, a conventional metaphor for dispersion.

instances.english_text: from all the places to which they had scattered / been driven
target: the forced dispersion of Judeans by conquest and exile
vehicle: being driven/pushed away to various places
physical motion of items under impact
ground: exile resembles objects being forced away and dispersed in different directions
posture: narrator’s summary of the exiles’ past experience
instances.explanation: The verb ‘were driven/scattered’ metaphorically portrays the exiles as objects pushed and dispersed to many locations.

deliberation: Simple narrative of Johanan and the officers coming to Gedaliah. No idioms, metaphors, or personification beyond standard literal usage were detected.

The warning to Gedaliah is mostly literal. The expression ‘to strike you, nefesh’ (smite you, life) uses ‘soul/life’ as a part/aspect standing for the whole person, a synecdoche/metonymy for killing you.

instances.english_text: to kill you [lit. ‘to strike you, life/soul’]
target: the taking of a person’s life
ground: the life/soul represents the whole living person; to strike the life is to kill the person
posture: Johanan’s report of the assassination plot
warning framed in idiomatic death language
instances.explanation: ‘Strike you, nefesh’ uses ‘life/soul’ as a synecdoche for the person, an idiomatic metonymy for killing you.

deliberation: Explored Johanan’s proposal. Found (1) the same idiomatic ‘strike [someone], nefesh’ for killing, and (2) the depiction of the Judeans as ‘gathered’ and then ‘scattered,’ conceptualizing the community as objects that can be collected and dispersed.

instances.english_text: otherwise he will kill you [lit. ‘why should he strike you, life/soul?’]
target: the loss of a person’s life
ground: the life/soul stands for the whole person; striking the life equals killing the person
posture: Johanan’s secret argument to persuade Gedaliah
instances.explanation: Again ‘strike you, nefesh’ uses ‘life/soul’ as a synecdoche for the person, an idiomatic way to speak of killing.

instances.english_text: and all the Judeans who have gathered about you will be dispersed
target: the political and social breakup of the Judean community around Gedaliah
cohesion or dissolution of a community
vehicle: collection of items that can be broken apart
ground: a unified community is like gathered items; scattering them pictures the loss of unity and proximity
posture: Johanan’s warning about the consequences of Gedaliah’s death
vivid depiction of potential communal collapse
instances.explanation: The gathered Judeans are portrayed as a collection of items that can be ‘scattered,’ metaphorically describing political and social dispersal.

deliberation: Gedaliah’s rebuttal is simple denial. Phrases like ‘you are speaking a lie’ are straightforward moral evaluation of Johanan’s report, not figurative or idiomatic beyond normal usage.
